body: Considering this fixed as of 9b216c54669598ecfc4bd07ea9439eaabf4fc44e. The new approach looks like it should work fine.

What about creating a new email account specifically for gophish?  When you want to create a template you could just forward an email to that account, gophish will see the incoming email, and automatically import the email as a template.

Spam could be an issue.  Or not.  If you received any, then all of a sudden you've got some realistic phishing templates.

If you don't end up mirroring the external resources (CSS, JS, images, etc) then the HTML `<base>` tag is very useful.  You can just insert that tag at the beginning of the `<head>` with the URL that the site was originally hosted at and all of the relative URLs elsewhere will magically still work despite the page being hosted on another domain.

Using a `<base>` tag is a great idea! I've been considering whether or not to mirror external resources. There's pros and cons:

**Pros**
- More reliable and consistent page layout - if the site changes, the phishing site won't
- Removes trackers - this is really only important for pentesting engagements. Business training shouldn't care too much
- Quicker load times

**Cons**
- Need to implement XML parsing to find dependencies
- Need to create code to pull those down
- and change their links to be relative to the root
- and store them somewhere on the filesystem

I might do `0.1` using the `<base>` tag, but have a greyed out checkbox to "host external files locally" or "full mirror" or something like that.

Thanks for the suggestion!

This would be a **great** idea for a hosted solution. I considered offering something like this, but I think it falls under the same idea as having some domains people could use to do their phishing.

My assumption is that this, like most security tools, will inevitably be a  double-edged sword. If I host domains or email addresses bad guys use to do some of this stuff, it comes back on me. Instead, if I leave domain management, email management, etc. up to the user - it's on them.

However, that being said, I am still considering a hosted solution (might as well try to monetize this somehow without making it closed-source), and a gophish-specific email would be a great addition to that toolset.
Now that I think about it, removing tracking should be fairly easy to do with basic html parsing. Something like looking for any 1x1 image and removing it should work in most cases.
Closed via 8f7bce224b8a85fcebf8f0b759d8ce06e02e2276. Just finishing up bug fixes, etc.
Closed via 8f7bce224b8a85fcebf8f0b759d8ce06e02e2276 with migration to jQuery. JS is now in separate files.
Closed via fad36607e443c4209fb2e424bf55eecfeb86c2d7 - importing a site now works as expected!

Closed via 9b597fea921167f1a072f55bd49056151c6cfdcf.

You can use the `{{.Tracker}}` to get a full tracking image tag, while `{{TrackingURL}}` can be used to get just the URL.

Basic support added in b45a72618d944fe984a13e4fd5a51d8a1f13b989

Considering this closed.
Closing this, as I moved to Chartist.js with things starting to finish up around a78e92a436ce78eca71a345b5d49396b3fa72766.
This might be an "Enterprise" feature.
Looks like this was due to the CSRF whitelisting only being applied for `/*`.
I could also use [dygraphs](http://dygraphs.com/) specifically for the time series data. That allows zooming, but it would be difficult to make the look consistent.

Hey @harrifeng, you can try to change this line in `config.json`:

```
    "phish_url" : "0.0.0.0:80",
```

If you change that to something other than 80, that should fix your problem. I apologize for not having this documented. I know it looks like there hasn't been repo updates in a few days, but I've been working offline on better documentation in general. :smile: 

Let me know if this fixes the issue! If not, I'll be happy to help any way I can.
Hi @jordan-wright issue is fixed, thanks for your help!
Also, the bcrypt dependency is pointing to a deprecated location. Need to update it to the newest repo on golang.org.

Spot on - thanks man! I'll double check these tomorrow evening, but things look great.

I didn't even think about switching these to be gophish repo.
Ok, nvm, I think they look good so I'm going to go ahead and merge.

This is being moved to github.com/gophish/templates
Related to #56, since the datatables buttons can help out with this.

Hey @harso121, thanks for this report. I've seen this before when we recently switched the repo from my personal to the org.

Can you try a go get -u to see if this fixes the issue? If it doesn't, let me know and I'll get this knocked out this evening.

No, sadly same as before..
